author: Sophie Christie
title: Our pick of the best fixed-rate savings bonds
text:
• Our five favourite easy-access savings accounts Consider rates predictions 
Interest rates on savings accounts and Isas are influenced most by the UK Bank Rate , which means if this rises in the next year or two and you're locked into a five-year bond, you could miss out on better rates offered elsewhere. Bank Rate, which has remained at 0.5pc for the past six years, looks set to remain fixed for another year, according to recent predictions. 
But fixing your money into a one-, two- or three-year fixed-rate bond could be a good idea if the income meets your needs, and you're certain you won't need to touch the money during the fixed term. 
You should compare these fixed rates to the best variable rates on offer: Our five favourite easy-access savings accounts Best fixed-rate bonds 
ONE YEAR 
Charter Savings Bank pays the best rate at 2.06pc on balances above £1,000. From tomorrow (July 17) Paragon Bank will pay a slightly better rate at 2.07pc on balances above £1,000. 
TWO YEARS 
Secure Trust pays the top rate, at 2.33pc, on minimum deposits of £1,000. Accounts can be opened by post or over the phone. Interest must be paid away and cannot be added and compounded to the account. 
Alternatively, Vanquis Bank pays 2.26pc on £1,000 and above, with interest added and compounded and paid annually or monthly. Apply online only. 
THREE YEARS 
Charter Savings Bank offers the best rate at 2.65pc on deposits of £1,000 or more. Interest is paid annually or monthly, and savers can apply online. 
FOUR YEARS 
Charter Savings Bank pays 2.75pc again on deposits of £1,000 or more. Interest is paid annually or monthly, and savers can apply online. 
FIVE YEARS 
Paragon Bank offers a top rate of 3.06pc on its five-year bond, which requires a minimum deposit of £1,000. Interest is paid annually or monthly, and savers can apply online. High Interest Paying Current Accounts Bank
